intro: Fumaria gaillardotii subsp. major, commonly known as the greater celandine, is a member of the Papaveraceae family. It is a herbaceous perennial plant characterized by its fleshy, ribbed stems and alternate, lanceolate leaves. The plant produces bright yellow flowers with a distinctive spurred petal, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its roots contain alkaloids and have been used historically in traditional medicine. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in meadows, roadsides, and waste areas.
